results.title: B.B.C. television: the first 25 years
results.brief_description: Describes Britain’s pioneering efforts with this medium, showing how the demands of war accelerated technical development and how the post-war years nursed the nation-wide impact of this home entertainment. The opening of the first regular television service from Alexandra Palace, London, in 1936; highlights from popular programmes and the linking of the BBC service with Eurovision and Intervision 25 years later. A record of successful transmission from Britain to Australia indicates a path of future achievement.

results.title: Ayers Rock; Brick and Tile; Incongruous
results.brief_description: A collection of three experimental films made by filmmaker, Paul Winkler. These films present fascinating combinations, juxtapositions and manipulation of moving and still images. The first film makes use of images of the Ayers Rock, Australian bushland, and patterns from aboriginal bark paintings. The second film uses images of bricks and tiles. The last film shows juxtaposition of rural and urban images. Each film has an interesting soundtrack, matching the moving images.

results.title: Ayers Rock
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Arid Landforms”.
Gives examples of Australian landforms resulting from weathering and erosion in arid regions. Illustrates examples of weathering and erosion responsible for producing the features seen in Ayers Rock. Shows three types of residuals found in arid Central Australia, kinds of weathering responsible for the formation of Ayers Rock and emphasises geological time periods. Also notes in detail the caves, grooves and guttering, and the under-cut base caused by running water. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Axemanship
results.creator_credit: Boy Scouts of America. Visual Education Service
results.brief_description: Peter McLarin who has held world records for chopping in England, Australia and the United States, demonstrates the proper use and care of an axe. Principles of safety and efficiency are stressed.

results.title: Avoiding danger
results.creator_credit: National Association of Citizens Advice Bureau and Paul White
results.brief_description: In July 1986 Estate Agent, Suzy Lamplugh, disappeared while on a client appointment. The Suzy Lamplugh Trust was set up to encourage increased awareness among employers and staff of the potential danger from attack in the workplace. The Trust is engaged in comprehensive research in the field of personal vulnerability, and is developing courses to promote greater understanding of the ways to minimise risk. There are practical steps that everyone can take. First, AVOID potential risk by following cautionary procedures. TALK in ways that will placate rather than provoke customers or clients who are aggressive. WALK away from danger. DEFEND yourself if all other methods fail.

results.title: Avalanche (Captioned)
results.brief_description: Filmed on location in the Austrian Tyrol, AVALANCHE is an action packed tale of adventure on a snow holiday. Despite strict regulations imposed by their teacher, two boys set out to climb the mountain. Disaster and gripping drama follow. Rated: G

results.title: Auxiliary views: single auxiliaries
results.creator_credit: Pathescope Company of America and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Engineering Drawing”.
Begins with a brief review of the principles of orthographic projection and goes on to show that the three views obtained by projection on the three principal planes do not represent the true shape of some surfaces of an object that has one or more slanting faces. This condition is shown to require projection of the slanting surface on a plane which is parallel to it and not one of the principal planes. Thus auxiliary projection is explained and defined.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Pathescope Company of America and McGraw-Hill Films

group_siblings.title: Auxiliary views: double auxiliaries
group_siblings.creator_credit: Pathescope Company of America and McGraw-Hill Films

results.title: Auxiliary views: double auxiliaries
results.creator_credit: Pathescope Company of America and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Engineering Drawing”.
Begins with a quick view of orthographic projection on three principal planes and on auxiliary planes; then points out that a new condition is introduced if the object to be drawn has a slanting face that is not perpendicular to any of the principal planes. The film shows why a single auxiliary view does not give an accurate picture of an oblique face. The theory of double auxiliary or oblique view is then described in detail, using the visualization effects of combined animated drawings and animated models.

results.title: Auxiliary views. Pt. 1
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mechanical Drawing”.
Begins by showing that the three principal views do not represent the true surface of an object that has one or more slanting faces. This condition is shown to require projection of the slanting surface on a plane which is parallel to it and is not one of the principle planes. This auxiliary projection is explained and defined. No other credits available.
